titleStmt.title: AN
Tale of a Nettle,
PARAGRAPH by PARAGRAPH.
From the Best
EDITION,
Printed at
CAMBRIDGE,
At the Request of several of the

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: The KEY.
LIne 1 and 2. The State of the Church of England at that time.
2 and 4. Forms of Prayers in the Liturgy.
5. No Presbyterians in those Days.
7 and 8. About 1626, they began to molest.
9, 10. Some Bishops would have rooted them out, and have sent them from whence they came.
15 and 16 The Protestants that fled from most parts of Europe to Enland, in Queen Elizabeth's time, to avoid Persecution.
17 and 18. Because they would not renounce their Religion, and turn Romans.
21 and 22. See their Petition to Queen Elizabeth for Places of Worship for their own Use.
23 and 24. Rights and Ceromonies of the Church of England.
24 and 25. Forms of Prayer in the Liturgy.
27 and 28. See farther their Petition to Queen Elizabeth.
33 and 34. The Good Man, meaning the Church of England.
35 and 56. The Toleration Act.
37 and 38. The Church of England's Compassion to the Refugees.
41 and 42. The Master, (meaning the Church of England.)
45 and 46. The Off spring of those Refugees.
47 and 48. The Persecution of the Church of England at this time.
51 and 52. The Toleration: By which 'tis thought, and seems very probable, that we have more Dissenters of several sorts in England than Churchmen.
An Explanation of the First Paragraph.

THE Glory of England was arrived to a high pitch in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, how Happy her Subjects were under her Auspicious Reign, the Roman Yoak being thrown off, which England for many Years before had born;
Long had the Roman Harlot's wanton Charms,
Entic'd all Europe to her Sinful Arms;
England among the rest, by Fame betray'd,
Carress'd th' Adultress for a Spotless Maid;
Ador'd that Beauty which was only Paint,
And hugg'd the Splendid Strumpet for a Saint.

Being got rid of this Plague, together with the fortunate Success of her Arms Abroad, no Nation in Europe, at that time, made a more Glorious Show than England, being a Terror to her Enemies, and a Place of Refuge to People of several Nations, whose Tender Consciences compell'd them to fly their Native Country, which came flocking to her, being allowed several Places of Worship, according to their different Opinions in Religion, which since has created too many Differences among us.
Some Bishops, (or as here express'd the Gardiner) would have sent them back again, to stop the encrease of a Barbarous Crop, which has been Barbarous to our Sorrow.
An Explanation of the Second Paragraph.

No Church on this side the Apostolick, can hardly, or ever could, compare with the Church of England for Piety and Learning; she might probably have continu'd, without Dissention had not she been distrub'd by a Generation of Hypocritical (or at least Blind) Zealots, whose Predecessors (in Queen Elizabeth's Time) began to oppose that excellent well-begun Reformation, who are thus describ'd;
Dutch, Walloons, Flemings, Irish-men, and Scots,
Vaudois, and Valtolins, and Hugonots,
In good Queen Bess's Charitable Reign,
Supply'd us with Three hundred thousand Men;
Religion (God we thank thee) sent them hither,
Priests, Protestants, the Devil and all together;
Of all Professions, and of ev'ry Trade,
All that were Persecuted, or afraid,
Whether for Debt, or other Crimes they fled,
David of Hackelah was still their Head.
The Off-spring of this Miscellaneous Brood,
Had not their New Plantations long enjoy'd
But they grew English-men, and rais'd their Votes
'Gainst Foreign Shoals of Interloping Scots.
All come with pretence of shunning Persecution, but now none more willing to Persecute than their Brethren.
Tho' they would not Subscribe to a Mystery Dark then, they will now, and will make us know, if the Jesuit-Bark (or Roman Religion) is not a Sacred Doctrine, Resistance and the power of the People is.
The Errors of the Roman Church is an Erroneous Tenet, but Resistance, and the Power of the People, is an Impudent one.

Tho your Digging and Dunging, my Nature much harms, (meaning the Rights and Ceremonies of the Church of England) that cannot comply with their Gardiner in Forms, (or using precompos'd Forms of Prayer in Churches.)
An Explanation of the Third Paragraph.

The P──sb──ns, who have had all the Privileges a People can (in Reason) expect from a Queen and Government, the exercise of their Religion without interruption, several Honours conferred upon them more than the C────h, their Religion Establish'd, and Tolereted by Law, but now they forget the Good Man who was won by their plausible Tale;
Who Welcom'd and gave 'em free Toleration,
In the midst of the Garden to take up their Station.
Remember ye Varlets, how your Factious Race,
Were justly Scourg'd by a true Son of Grace:
May the bold Truths with which he warmed St. Paul's,
Live and be lasting as her Sacred Walls;
Heav'n long preserve him then, and when he Dies,
May the like Phænix from his Dust arise.
Hold good Master Nettle, remember your promise you formerly made,
If we wou'd but allow you a Place for to rest in
Among the rest of the Trees, you'd ne'er be Molesting;
If a kind Shelter to you we wou'd afford,
You'd do us no harm, you gave us your Word.
Come Mr. Nettle, we must have a Bill to prevent this O────nal Confrmity, none shall go to Church to get Places of Honour, without they'll renounce their Conventicles for the future.
The Devil you will, cries one, we have Liberty of Conscience now, we'll make you Rue the O────nal Bill as long as you Live.
An Explanation of the Fifth Paragraph.
The Master; (meaning the Compassionate Church of England)
Who welcom'd his Guest, gave him free Toleration
In the midst of his Garden to take up his Station,
And into his Bosom the Presbyter brought,
That the Presbyter would Sting, the Good Man ne'er thought.

At this Time the Nettle Stings sadly; but whose Fault is it Gentlement? We should have thought of this before, and not have deliver'd the Staff out of our own Hand; the Trees now must beg a Place among the Nettles, they can be but Nettl'd if they come to them; snd be they ne'er so far off, they will make them come to them to be Netled, and thank God they can come off so, without being Cut down, or pluck'd up by the Roots, and hung up to Dry, or Nailed against the Wall at the lower end of the Garden, or any where, so they may not molest them.

Since one Nettle uncropt increased to such store,
Let us all try to ────and ────them full sore,
And take care that we are deceived so no more,
But keep the Trees in our Garden, as we us'd before.
PARAGRAPH·I.
A MAN with Expence of wonderful Toil,
By Planting and Dunging Enobled his Soil;
There Fruits of the Best his Taste did invite,
And uniform Order still courted the Sight:
No degenerate Weed the Rich Ground did produce,
And all Things afforded both Beauty and Use;
Till from Dunghill transplanted, while yet but a Seed
A NETTLE rear'd up his Inglorious Head:
The Gard'ner wou'd wisely have rooted him up,
To stop the Increase of a Barbarous Crop;
But the Master forbad him, and after the Fashion,
of foolish good Nature, and blind Moderation;
Forbore him thro' Pity, and chose, as much rather
To ask him some Questions first, how he came thither.
PARAGRAPH·II.
Kind Sir, quoth the Nettle, a Stranger I come;.
For Conscience compell'd to relinquish my Home;
'Cause I wou·d not subscribe to a Mystery Dark,
That the Prince of all Trees was the Jesuits Bark.
An Erroneous Tenet, I know, Sir, that you
Know more than my self will allow to be true;
To you I for Refuge and Sanctuary sue,
There's none so renown'd for Compassion as you:
And tho' in some Things I may differ from these
The rest of the Faithful and Beautiful Trees;
Tho' your Digging and Dunging my Nature much harms,
And I cannot comply with the Gard'ner in Forms;
Yet I and our Family after our Fashion,
Will peaceably stick to our own Education;
Be pleas'd to allow us a Place for to rest in,
'Mongst the rest of the Trees, we'll never molest 'em.
A kind Shelter to us, and Protection afford,
We'll do you no harm, I'll give you my Word
PARAGRAPH·III.
The good man was soon won by this plausible Tale,
(So Fraud on Good Nature does often prevail.)
He welcoms his Guest, gives him free Toleration
In the midst of his Garden to take up his Station;
And into his Bosom does his Enemy bring;
He never suspected the NETTLE wou'd Sting:
Still flush'd with Success of Strength to be fear'd,
Around him a numerous Off-spring he rear'd.
PARAGRAPH·IV.
Then the Master grew sensible what he had done,
And fain wou'd have had his new Guest to be gone;
But now 'twas too late to bid him turn out,
A well-rooted Possession already was got:
The old Trees decay'd, and in their room grew,
A stubborn, rank, pestilent, poysonous Crew.
PARAGRAPH·V.
The Master who first that young Brood had admitted,
They stung like Ingrates, and left him unpitied;
No help from Manuring and Planting was found,
The Weeds had eat out the Heart of the Ground,
Thus one Nettle uncropt increas'd to such store,
That 'twas nothing but Weeds, what was Garden before.
